review.title: Early Predictions of Movie Success: the Who, What, and When of Profitability
review.abstract: This paper proposes a decision support system to aid movie investment decisions at the early stage of movie productions. The system predicts the success of a movie based on its profitability by leveraging historical data from various sources. Using social network analysis and text mining techniques, the system automatically extracts several groups of features, including "who" are on the cast, "what" a movie is about, "when" a movie will be released, as well as "hybrid" features that match "who" with "what", and "when" with "what". Our experiments with movies during an 11-year period showcase the system's decent performance in predicting movie success. Moreover, experiment results also suggest that different groups of features, including novel features we proposed, all contribute to the prediction.

sections.heading: 3 The system framework
sections.text: Figure 1 illustrates the scope of our MIAS. The first phase is data collection, as we base our prediction on historical data. While there are various online archives of movie data, we chose two popular and complementary sources - IMDb and BoxOfficeMojo. IMDb provides better coverage of movie action synopses, while BoxOfficeMojo, as the name suggests, provides more comprehensive data on movie revenue and budgets. In other words, the two data sources can be used together for many movies. As with data collection methods, the two sources are different. IMDb has a handy API that can be used to collect movie data in JSON or XML. Data from BoxOfficeMojo can only be obtained from websites. To get a more comprehensive dataset, our system uses scripts that interact with APIs as well as a webscaper to retrieve and analyze HTML data from websites.

sections.heading: 5.1 Dataset and Basic Statistics
sections.text: Our original dataset, collected by both BoxOfficeMojo and IMDb, consisted of 14,097 films, along with 4,420 actors. While the films in our dataset date back to 1921, we focused our study on films released during the 11-year period of 2000-2010 (including), as this period is young enough to reflect the current state of the industry, and there has been sufficient time elapsed since the films were released for revenue data to be accurately updated. Since our goal is to predict the success of the film based on profits, our dataset for experimentation included only those films that have both budget and revenue, and we excluded films with an "unknown" genre or "unknown" MPAA rating. Movies with a "documentary" genre were also excluded, as they are generally not released in theaters and may not involve professional actors.

sections.heading: 5.2 The measure of success
sections.text: To predict whether a film is successful, we first need to measure the return on investment (ROI) of a film. As both revenue and budget data are available for each film in our dataset, we can calculate the gross return (i.e. the return budget) for each film. Gross return distribution in Figure 4 seems to follow a normal distribution - a large number of films have near-zero returns. As only 36% of the films in our dataset have positive returns, investors need a decision support system to help them choose the right film to invest in. Although using return values is intuitive, the $10,000 gain from a film that costs $1 million to produce is certainly not an attractive investment. Therefore, in our experiments we have chosen a popular metric for return on investment (ROI), as in [9]. It takes into account both profit and budget and is defined in Equation 6. The higher the ROI, the more profitable a film is and vice versa.

sections.heading: 5.3 Classification results
sections.text: Predicting the success of a film is essentially a classification problem, where we classify films into discrete containers or classes. Then, the problem is to decide whether a film should be considered a success or not, based on ROI. Although there is no agreed "gold standard" for an ideal ROI (except that "higher is better"), it is reasonable to assume that you want to see some substantial returns from a successful film, since millions of dollars are invested with significant risks. Also, any form of profit is better than a loss. Against this background, we have chosen to define the boundary between successful and unsuccessful films in different ways, for both binary and multi-class predictions.

sections.heading: 5.3.1 Binary classification
sections.text: In the case of binary classifications, a film is divided into one of two classes: successful or unsuccessful films. Two decision limits are evaluated, and both ensure that a sufficient ROI is garnished if a film is considered successful. 1. The first decision limit is that a film is considered successful if its ROI is within 30% of all films. To our dataset, this profitability threshold means a ROI of 24%. The performance of the two best classification algorithms is listed in Table 2, with a Random Forest classifier (n = 200) generating the highest AUC and a logistic regression classifier leading in accuracy and F1 Score.Table 3 shows the results when a group of features is removed from the classifier. As can be seen, the performance of the classifier deteriorates when a group of features is removed, indicating that each of the five groups, including the novel features we have proposed, contributes to predicting child success.

sections.heading: 5.3.2 Multi-class classification
sections.text: In the case of multi-class classifications, we define three possible classes for a film: positive ("success"), negative ("failure") or neutral ("average"), in order to provide the investor with more information on where he could expect a film to decline in terms of profitability. In terms of multi-class prediction, we investigated the costs associated with a misclassification, because the three classes are ordinary, while binary classes are nominal. In other words, not all errors in misclassification of a film are equally serious. For example, predicting success in supporting investment decisions would be worse than predicting a neutral film. sections.heading: 6 Discussions
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 6.1 Important features for prediction
sections.text: In illustrating the performance of our prediction models, we also showed that each of the five sets of characteristics contributed differently to the prediction. In addition to the five sets of characteristics, it is also important to understand the contributions of our individual characteristics. First, we ranked characteristics based on their information gain. Table 8 lists top characteristics in each characteristic category and their overall ranking among all 111 characteristics of our prediction model. As we can observe, each category contains characteristics that rank among all characteristics in the top 50. Many of the new characteristics that we have proposed are highly rated in several categories, such as cast novelty, change in clustering coefficient, annual weighted profitability by genre, and annual profitability performance by genre. We also acknowledge that several "classic" characteristics that were typically included in film-related prediction models were also considered significant contributors, including an "R" rating success by genre and the Foreign Relationship of an actor's "star rating among all of the categories.

sections.heading: 6.2 Predictability
sections.text: In order to better understand which types of films are more predictable in terms of profitability, we analyzed the predictability of films based on the period of release and the Star Powers, since films released during the holidays or with high Star Powers often generate high box office revenues [19, 20]. Predictability is measured by predictive accuracy. However, it turns out that these films, which are likely to generate high revenues, are also the most difficult to predict: films that sell better at the box office (6a) and films with the highest Star Powers (6b) receive the least predictability. The low predictability of profits for these films, which are likely to generate high revenues, further illustrates the discrepancy between revenues and profits: films that sell better at the box office may also require larger investments and therefore do not necessarily guarantee satisfactory returns for investors. This uncertainty about the success of high-stakes films underscores the need for our decision-making component, in addition to the fact that we always anticipate high performance from the previous system.

sections.heading: 6.3 Limitations
sections.text: Admittedly, our study has limitations. First, as we have already mentioned, there are potential distortions in our sample. As Figure 3 shows, our data set is relatively representative in terms of film genres. However, the limited availability of both budget and revenue data could lead to a distortion of our data set for the experiment, even though we exclude only 17% of all films produced within the 11-year period, as both types of data are missing. Another limitation is that the profit we calculate is based on production budgets and box office revenue. For many films, box office revenue is only one source. For example, Disney's animated films often generate a significant portion of their revenue from the sale of film merchandise such as clothing and toys. In addition to ticket sales, some films also depend heavily on the sale and rental of DVDs. However, capturing this revenue outside the box office is more difficult as they may continue to accumulate for many years after the release of a film.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and future work
sections.text: MIAS learns from freely available historical data from various sources and tries to predict the success of films that are defined by profitability, not revenue, as most studies have done. Because investment decisions are made very early in the production process, our system uses only data that is available early. These features include both classic and novel features that were first proposed, describing "who" is cast from both an individual and a network perspective, "which" includes a movie in terms of genre, rating and plot synopsis issues when "a movie is released, as well as" hybrid "features that" coincide with "what" and "when." Our experiments are based on 11 years of films that show that MIAS can do a decent job in predicting the success of films. In addition, various sets of features, including new features that we propose to capture the impact of this framework, will not coincide with the popularity of films. "

metadata.abstractText: This paper proposes a decision support system to aid movie investment decisions at the early stage of movie productions. The system predicts the success of a movie based on its profitability by leveraging historical data from various sources. Using social network analysis and text mining techniques, the system automatically extracts several groups of features, including “who” are on the cast, “what” a movie is about, “when” a movie will be released, as well as “hybrid” features that match “who” with “what”, and “when” with “what”. Our experiments with movies during an 11-year period showcase the system’s decent performance in predicting movie success. Moreover, experiment results also suggest that different groups of features, including novel features we proposed, all contribute to the prediction.
